comment.author: 69662531@N05
comment._content:
From the Commonwealth War Graves Commission website:

Name:UNIACKE, HENRY PERCY
Initials:H P
Nationality:United Kingdom
Rank:Lieutenant Colonel
Regiment/Service:Gordon Highlanders
Unit Text:2nd Bn.
Age:52
Date of Death:13/03/1915
Awards:C B
Additional information:Eldest son of the late Capt. Turner Uniacke (19th Regt. of Foot) and Isabella Louise Fortescue Uniacke; husband of Flora Uniacke (grand-daughter of 5th Earl of Ormerley), of Upper Corsee, Banchory, Kincardineshire.
Casualty Type:Commonwealth War Dead
Grave/Memorial Reference:II. F. 8.
Cemetery:ESTAIRES COMMUNAL CEMETERY AND EXTENSION

comment.author: 69717788@N04
comment._content: Lieutenant Colonel Henry Percy Uniacke CB, officer commanding the 2nd Battalion, the Gordon Highlanders. Son of Henry Turner and his wife Isabella Louisa Uniacke (née Fortescue); husband of Flora Alexandra Lucy Uniacke (née Schuster). Born in Newton Abbot 13 September 1862. Served with his Regiment in the Tirah Campaign. Severely wounded in the head 29 October 1914 at Ypres. Resumed command of his Battalion 26 January 1915. Mentioned in Sir John French's Despatches and awarded the CB (Companion of the Order of the Bath). Died 13 March 1915 as a result of his wounds aged 52

comment.author: 42694764@N00
comment._content:
From 'The Times' March 17 1915
News has been received in London of the death in action at Neuve Chapelle on the 13th inst. of Lieutenant-Colonel H. P. Uniacke, commanding the 2nd Battalion Gordon Highlanders.
Lieutenant-Colonel Uniacke served with his regiment in the Tirah campaign, being wounded and mentioned in dispatches. He afterwards commanded the depot at Aberdeen and in December 1911 became commanding officer of the second battalion, which he brought from Cairo on the outbreak of war. He was severely wounded in the head by Shrapnel on October 29, in the battle of Ypres, but resumed command of his battalion in France on January 26. He was mentioned in Sir John French's dispatches and was made C.B. in the last list of honours, Lieutenant-Colonel Uniacke, whose home was Corsee, Banchory, was the eldest son of the late Captain Uniacke, of Laywell, Devonshire (who took part in the charge of the Light Brigade), and married, in 1896, Flora, daughter of the late Mr. Leo and Lady Isabelle Schuster.

comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content: In this photograph Lieutenant Colonel Uniacke appears to have contrived to put the strap of his Sam Browne belt over the wrong shoulder, (though this might be a photographer's studio 'prop'). There is a 1912 group photograph of Gordon Highlanders officers, on leave from India, taken at Kirkaldy at colintonpcs.co.uk/LMA/main.php?g2_itemId=386 Henry Uniacke might be the fourth officer from the right in the front row.//

comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content: The visible medal ribbon is likely to be that for the Delhi Durbar Medal awarded to commemorate the Coronation of King George V in 1911.  (Expert opinion provided courtesy of Worcestershire Medal Services). The ribbon is 35mm wide, True Blue with two Vermilion Red stripes.//

comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content: Having served in the Tirah campaign, 2 October 1897- 31 January 1898, Henry Percy Uniacke would have been awarded the India General Service Medal 1895-1902 with the bar for Tirah 1897-98. The ribbon for this is 35mm wide, in stripes of equal fifths, two Carmine Red stripes on Indian Green. The correct order of precedence would have placed the India GSM to be worn before the Delhi Durbar (Coronation) medal - Colonel Uniacke may have covered his medal ribbons to disguise this apparent tailor's error on his uniform. The Tirah campaign included the storming of the Dargai Heights by the 1st Battalion Gordon Highlanders which is where Captain Uniacke was wounded on 20th October 1897. The Gordons won 2 Victoria Crosses there (Piper Findlater and Private Lawson). Details at: www.dnw.co.uk/medals/auctionarchive/searchcataloguearchiv... //

Note:  
The Army Foundation College in Harrogate (abbreviated AFC(H)) trains future soldiers from the infantry, armoured corps, artillery and elements of the Royal Logistic Corps (RLC). Situated in Uniacke Barracks in Harrogate named after Lieutenant General Sir Herbert Uniacke.  (Wikipedia articles)
Herbert Uniacke (1866-1934) does not seem to be in this household as a younger brother of Henry Percy  Uniacke (1862-1915)
